questions.text: A patient is being treated with phenobarbitone. Which of the following is inhibited? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Complex I → coenzyme Q


Phenobarbitone is known to affect the electron transport chain, specifically inhibiting the transfer of electrons from Complex I to coenzyme Q. Complex I, also known as NADH dehydrogenase and NADH CoQ oxidoreductase, takes hydrogen from NADH and transfers electrons to coenzyme Q (ubiquinone). This step is crucial in the electron transport chain as it initiates the flow of electrons, which is essential for ATP production. Phenobarbitone inhibits this specific step, disrupting the electron flow, which impairs cellular energy production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Complex II → coenzyme Q: This step involves the transfer of electrons from succinate to coenzyme Q, a different pathway not directly affected by phenobarbitone.

 

Option C. Complex III → Cyt. C: This step transfers electrons from coenzyme Q to cytochrome C, an independent part of the electron transport chain not impacted by phenobarbitone.

 

Option D. Complex IV → oxygen: This final step involves the transfer of electrons to oxygen, forming water. Phenobarbitone does not inhibit this part of the chain.

 

Educational Objective:


Phenobarbitone specifically inhibits the electron transport between Complex I and coenzyme Q, disrupting ATP production.

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese female presented with Schizophrenia. Which of the following antipsychotic drug causes least weight gain? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ziprasidone

 

Ziprasidone is known to cause less weight gain compared to many other antipsychotics, making it a more suitable option for an obese patient concerned about further weight gain. Clozapine and olanzapine, in particular, are associated with a higher risk of significant weight gain and metabolic changes. Chlorpromazine, while potentially causing weight gain, is generally not as strongly linked to this side effect as clozapine or olanzapine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chlorpromazine: This is a typical antipsychotic. These drugs can cause weight gain, though chlorpromazine is not as strongly associated with weight gain as some atypical antipsychotics.

 

Option B. Clozapine: Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic known for causing significant weight gain, along with other metabolic effects.

 

Option C. Olanzapine: Olanzapine is another atypical antipsychotic that is frequently associated with substantial weight gain and metabolic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ziprasidone is an atypical antipsychotic associated with a lower risk of weight gain. It is considered more weight-neutral compared to other atypical antipsychotics like clozapine and olanzapine.

questions.text: Graft from identical twin is called: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Isograft

 

An isograft is a type of graft where the donor and the recipient are genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins. This type of graft has the lowest risk of rejection because the donor and recipient have the same genetic makeup, which means their tissues are immunologically compatible.

 

Types of Grafts:

 

Option A. Allograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft where the donor and recipient are of the same species but have different genotypes.
  • Examples: Organ transplants between two different individuals (e.g., kidney transplant from one person to another non-twin individual).

 

Option B. Autograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft where the donor and recipient are the same person.
  • Examples: Skin grafts taken from one part of the body and transplanted to another part of the same individual's body.

 

Option C. Isograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft between two individuals who are genetically identical, such as identical twins.
  • Examples: Organ or tissue transplants between identical twins.

 

Option D. Xenograft:

 

  • Definition: A graft where the donor and recipient are of different species.
  • Examples: Transplantation of animal tissues or organs into humans, such as pig heart valves used in human heart surgery.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Autografts are grafts in which both the donor and the recipient are the same person.
  • Isografts are grafts that occur between donors and recipients who share the same genotype. An isograft is a graft from an identical twin
  • Allografts are those in which the donor and recipient are of the same species but of a different genotype.
  • Xenografts are those in which the donor and recipient are of different species.

questions.text: Which of the following abnormalities are likely to be associated with imperforate anus? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Esophageal atresia

 

Explanation:

 

Anorectal malformations (including imperforate anus) commonly occur with other congenital anomalies. The sacrum and genitourinary tract are often abnormal in these patients. Esophageal atresia frequently coexists with imperforate anus as part of the VACTERL association, where the "A" stands for anorectal malformations and the "E" for esophageal atresia. This embryological connection makes esophageal atresia the most likely associated abnormality from the given options.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A (Pulmonary airway malformation): Not typically associated with anorectal malformations. While respiratory abnormalities can occur in complex syndromes, this specific malformation is not a common association.
  • Option B (Duodenal atresia): Though duodenal atresia is a significant congenital malformation, it has stronger associations with Down syndrome rather than with imperforate anus.
  • Option D (Hydrocephalus): Not commonly associated with imperforate anus. Neurological conditions are not typical components of the syndromes that include anorectal malformations.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Imperforate anus frequently occurs with other congenital anomalies, particularly those affecting the sacrum, genitourinary tract, and other components of the VACTERL association, which includes esophageal atresia.

questions.text: A baby presents with the clinical features shown in the image, including characteristic perioral and perianal rash along with a history of diarrhea, delayed wound healing. Which of the following is the most likely deficiency responsible for this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zinc deficiency

 

The case describes a classic presentation of zinc deficiency with the characteristic Features:

 

  1. Periorificial dermatitis (perioral and perianal rash as shown in images)
  2. Diarrhea
  3. Delayed wound healing

 

The mnemonic "HIDE" helps remember the key features of zinc deficiency:

 

  • H: Healing (delayed wound healing)
  • I: Immunity (decreased)
  • D: Dermatitis (periorificial/acral)
  • E: Enteropathy (diarrhea)

 

Additional features can include:

 

  • Alopecia (hair loss)
  • Growth retardation
  • Impaired taste sensation
  • Secondary infections due to compromised immunity

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Niacin deficiency (Incorrect):

 

  • Presents with pellagra characterized by 3Ds: Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia
  • Dermatitis in pellagra shows casal’s Necklace appearance on sun-exposed areas, not periorificial
  • Dementia is not present in this case

 

Option C. Selenium deficiency (Incorrect):

 

  • Presents as Keshan disease with cardiomyopathy
  • Does not cause characteristic periorificial lesions or diarrhea
  • More common in areas with selenium-deficient soil

 

Option D. Magnesium deficiency (Incorrect):

 

  • Primarily presents with neuromuscular symptoms like tetany and seizures
  • Does not cause characteristic skin lesions or chronic diarrhea
  • Usually associated with malabsorption or alcoholism

 

Educational Objective:

 

Remember the characteristic clinical presentation of zinc deficiency using the mnemonic "HIDE" - Healing (delayed), Immunity (decreased), Dermatitis (periorificial), and Enteropathy (diarrhea). The periorificial distribution of dermatitis is pathognomonic for zinc deficiency.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of dizziness and weakness. She reports a history of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting for weight control. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals the following: (FMGE JAN 2025)

 

  • pH: 7.50
  • PaCO₂: 48 mmHg
  • HCO₃: 33 mmol/L

 

What is the most likely acid-base disturbance in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic alkalosis

 

Explanation:

 

This patient has metabolic alkalosis due to:

 

  • Elevated pH (> 7.45), indicating alkalemia.
  • Elevated HCO₃ (> 26 mEq/L), indicating metabolic alkalosis.
  • Clinical history of vomiting, which leads to the loss of chloride (via gastric acid - Hcl), resulting in hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.
  • Binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting suggests that the patient may suffer from bulimia nervosa, a psychiatric illness.
  • Compensatory increase in PaCO₂ (normal: 35-45 mmHg), as per expected compensation using the Modified Winter's formula for Metabolic Alkalosis:
    • Expected PaCO₂ = 0.7 × HCO₃ + 20 (or) 0.9 × HCO₃ + 16
    • In this case, let us use the second one: 0.9 × 33 + 16 = 45.7 mmHg (± 2)
      So the expected range would be 44-48 mm Hg. 
    • The patient’s PaCO₂ of 48 mmHg falls within the expected range. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic acidosis: Incorrect, as this would present with low pH (<7.4) and low HCO₃ (<24)

 

Option C. Respiratory acidosis: Incorrect, as the patient’s pH is 7.5 (alkalotic) and in acidosis pH would generally be low (< 7.4)

 

Option D. Respiratory alkalosis: Incorrect, as this would present with low PaCO₂ (< 40) and high pH (>7.4)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic vomiting results in loss of chloride (in the vomitus), resulting in hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Metabolic Alkalosis is usually characterized by elevated pH and HCO₃, with appropriate respiratory compensation (elevated PaCO₂ - due to hypoventilation).

choices.text: Obtaining sexual pleasure by wearing clothes of opposite sex
Desire to seek surgery to become member of opposite sex
Sexual gratification by rubbing his private parts against another person
Exposure of one's genitals to an unsuspecting stranger

questions.text: Frotteurism is defined as: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sexual gratification by rubbing his private parts against another person

 

Frotteurism involves the act of touching or rubbing one's genitals against another non-consenting individual in a sexual manner, to attain sexual gratification.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Obtaining sexual pleasure by wearing clothes of opposite sex

 

  • Term: Eonism (also known as Transvestism)
  • Description: Involves obtaining sexual pleasure or emotional satisfaction by wearing clothes traditionally associated with the opposite sex.

 

Option B. Desire to seek surgery to become a member of opposite sex

 

  • Term: Transsexualism
  • Description: Involves a strong desire to undergo surgery to change one's biological sex to align with one's gender identity.

 

Option D. Exposure of one's genitals to an unsuspecting stranger

 

  • Term: Exhibitionism
  • Description: Involves exposing one's genitals to an unsuspecting stranger for sexual gratification. This behavior is typically intended to shock or arouse the observer.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Act of rubbing one's genitals against another person without their consent to achieve sexual arousal or gratification - Frotteurism
  • Obtaining sexual pleasure by wearing clothes of opposite sex – Eonism
  • Desire to seek surgery to become member of opposite sex - Transsexualism
  • Exposure of one's genitals to an unsuspecting stranger- Exhibitionism

questions.text: Which biological molecule is most immunogenic? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A (Proteins).

 

Explanation:

 

Proteins are the most immunogenic biological molecules. Their high immunogenicity stems from their complex chemical structure and diversity of amino acid compositions, which provide numerous epitopes for immune recognition. Proteins are composed of about 20 different amino acid types, offering greater structural diversity compared to other biological molecules. This complexity and diversity make proteins highly recognizable by the immune system, leading to robust immune responses.

 

Immunogenicity referes to the ability of a substance (antigen) to provoke an immune response in the body — that is, to stimulate the production of antibodies or activate T-cells. Proteins are known to be the most immunogenic biological molecules.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Polysaccharides - While polysaccharides are antigenic, they are less immunogenic than proteins due to their simpler structure with fewer types of monosaccharide units. They generally elicit weaker immune responses.
  • Option C. Lipids - Lipids are poorly immunogenic by themselves. They typically need to be conjugated with carrier proteins to enhance their immunogenicity and stimulate an effective immune response.
  • Option D. Nucleic acids - Like lipids, nucleic acids have low immunogenicity. They also require protein conjugation to enhance their antigenicity and become effective immunogens.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Proteins possess the highest immunogenicity among biological molecules due to their complex structure, diverse amino acid composition, and ability to present multiple epitopes to the immune system.

questions.text: Which type of virus is rubella? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Togavirus

 

Rubella belongs to the Togaviridae family.

 

Rubella (German measles)

 

  • Causative organism belongs to family Togaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Incubation period: 2-3 weeks
  • Rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post infectious thrombocytopenia
  • Most serious complication: Encephalitis
  • Vaccination: 27/3 live attenuated

 

Congenital rubella syndrome:

 

  • When a woman in the 1st trimester gets infected with rubella, the resulting complications may include miscarriage, fetal death, premature delivery, or live birth with congenital defects.
  • The commonest malformations caused by rubella are cardiac defects, cataract, and deafness, which constitute the classical congenital rubella syndrome.
  • Thrombocytopenic purpura present in the babies gave rise to the term "blueberry muffin syndrome."

 

Expanded rubella syndrome:

 

  • Some babies present with several other features like hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenic purpura, myocarditis, and bone lesions constituting the expanded rubella syndrome.
  • This term also refers to a baby with metastatic neuroblastoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flavivirus: This group includes viruses like the West Nile virus and Dengue virus, not Rubella.

 

Option C. Paramyxovirus: Includes viruses like measles and mumps, which are clinically distinct from rubella.

 

Option D. Orthomyxovirus: This is the family of viruses that includes the influenza viruses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rubella, commonly known as German measles, is caused by a virus that belongs to the Togaviridae family, specifically the genus Rubivirus. This virus is typically transmitted via respiratory droplets and primarily causes a mild infection characterized by a rash, low fever, and swollen glands. However, its most significant health impact occurs when a pregnant woman is infected, particularly in the first trimester, leading to congenital rubella syndrome.

choices.text: Allergic Interstitial Nephritis
Urinary Tract Infection

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with follicular tonsillitis, for which antibiotics were prescribed. In a few days, the child developed flank pain and rash. Peripheral blood demonstrated eosinophilia, and urinalysis showed WBC casts. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Allergic Interstitial Nephritis

 

Allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN), also known as drug-induced interstitial nephritis, is an immune-mediated condition commonly caused by medications such as antibiotics (e.g., penicillins). The clinical presentation of AIN typically includes:

 

  • Recent medication use: In this case, antibiotics for follicular tonsillitis.
  • Flank pain and rash: These symptoms often develop a few days after starting the medication.
  • Eosinophilia: Elevated levels of eosinophils in peripheral blood are a hallmark of allergic reactions.
  • Urinalysis findings: Presence of white blood cell (WBC) casts in the urine indicates renal involvement.

 

The combination of these symptoms and laboratory findings strongly suggests allergic interstitial nephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyelonephritis: Pyelonephritis is characterized by fever, unilateral flank pain, and urinary symptoms like dysuria. It is usually associated with bacterial infection, not with recent antibiotic use or eosinophilia.

 

Option C. Berger Disease (IgA Nephropathy): IgA nephropathy, or Berger disease, is a glomerulonephritis characterized by hematuria and sometimes proteinuria. It does not typically present with rash, eosinophilia, or WBC casts.

 

Option D. Urinary Tract Infection (UTI): A UTI would present with urinary symptoms such as dysuria, frequency, and urgency. It can also lead to pyelonephritis, but it does not typically cause eosinophilia or WBC casts in the absence of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allergic interstitial nephritis is characterized by recent medication use (such as antibiotics), flank pain, rash, eosinophilia, and WBC casts in urine. It is an immune-mediated condition commonly caused by drugs, particularly antibiotics.

questions.text: A boy presented with a fever and chills. Rapid test was positive for specific antigen HRP-2. Which of the following species of Plasmodium is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmodium falciparum

 

Patient with given clinical symptoms and the HRP-2 positivity points to diagnosis of P. falciparum malaria.

 

This test is based on the detection of histidine-rich protein-2 (HRP-2), produced only by the asexual forms of Plasmodium falciparum, present on the surface of RBCs. It can detect only Plasmodium falciparum HRP-2 antigen but not the other three species of Plasmodium. Test remains positive until 2 weeks after the cure.

 

 

Another Kit test is Parasite lactate dehydrogenase (p LDH) which can detect all four Plasmodium species that infect humans.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plasmodium malariae: Not detected by the HRP-2 test.

 

Option C. Plasmodium vivax and Option D. Plasmodium ovale: Also not detected by the HRP-2 test. They would be identified by other rapid tests targeting different antigens like pLDH (Plasmodium Lactate Dehydrogenase).

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a rapid diagnosis of Plasmodium falciparum infection, the detection of the HRP-2 antigen is critical. This test is specific to P. falciparum, aiding in rapid treatment decisions crucial for preventing the severe complications associated with this malaria species.

questions.text: Which type of graph is used to illustrate studies on healthcare and disease prevalence in a population? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Ishikawa diagram/Fish bone diagram

 

Explanation

 

Ishikawa Diagram/Fish Bone Diagram/ Cause & Effect Diagram:

 

Description: A visual tool that helps trace a problem’s cause back to its roots, creating a branched diagram that looks like a fishbone.

 

Application: Used to identify, explore, and display the possible causes of a particular problem, particularly useful in quality control and prevention strategies in healthcare.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Bar Diagram:

 

Description: Bar diagrams use bars of varying lengths to represent data. Each bar corresponds to a category with a specific quantity.

 

Application: Useful for comparing quantities across different categories, such as the number of cases in different disease categories or patient counts in various demographic groups.

 

Option B. Histogram:

 

Description: A histogram is similar to a bar chart but is used for continuous quantitative data divided into bins or intervals. It helps in understanding the distribution of data.

 

Application: Commonly used to show the distribution of a dataset, such as the age distribution of patients suffering from a specific disease or the distribution of blood pressure readings in a population.

 

Option C. Multiple Regression Model:

 

Description: Not a graph, but a statistical technique that models the relationship between a dependent variable and multiple independent variables.

 

Application: Used to predict outcomes based on several variables, such as predicting patient outcomes based on age, treatment type, and pre-existing conditions.

 

Educational objectives : Fishbone diagrams are instrumental in root cause analysis, helping healthcare teams systematically investigate the contributory factors leading to health issues or outbreaks.

questions.text: Which of the following can be prescribed in case of an open angle glaucoma with bronchial asthma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Latanoprost

 

Latanoprost is a Prostaglandin, PGF2α analog, that acts in glaucoma by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor and is used as a first line drug in patients with open angle glaucoma. It can be safely used in bronchial asthma, as it does not cause bronchospasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: Timolol is a beta-blocker that can cause bronchospasm as a systemic side effect. Therefore, it is not recommended for patients with bronchial asthma.

 

Option B. Gemeprost: Gemeprost is a prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) analog used for the termination of pregnancy. It is not relevant for the treatment of glaucoma.

 

Option D. Mannitol infusion: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic used in the treatment of acute angle-closure glaucoma, not open-angle glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Latanoprost, a prostaglandin F2α analog, is safe and effective for the treatment of open-angle glaucoma in patients with bronchial asthma, as it does not cause bronchospasm.

choices.text: Abortion leading to death of mother
Preventing the child from being born alive

questions.text: IPC Section 314 deals with? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abortion leading to death of mother

 

ABORTION IPC’S = 312-316 IPC’S, 317 & 318

 

312 – 316 → Criminal Abortion

 

312 – Criminal abortion with consent of mother (BNS section 88)

 

313 – Criminal abortion without the consent of mother (BNS section 89)

 

314 – Death of mother during criminal abortion (BNS section 90)

 

315 - Preventing a live birth or causing a live born to die after birth (BNS section 91)

 

316 – Causing death of quick born, by a heinous act which could have led to death of mother (ex: - hit on abdomen of mother) (BNS section 92)

 

317 - Abandoning of a child by parents when child age is <12 years (BNS section 93)

 

318 - Concealing the birth of a newborn by secret disposal of dead body (BNS section 94)

 

Educational Objective:

 

IPC Section 314 deals specifically with the death of the mother during a criminal abortion.

choices.text: Dexamethasone 12 mg 24 hourly 2 doses
Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses
Betamethasone 12 mg 12 hourly 2 doses
Betamethasone 12 mg 24 hourly 4 doses

questions.text: What is the dose of corticosteroids for lung maturity? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses

 

Corticosteroids are administered to pregnant women who are at risk of preterm delivery (before 34 weeks of gestation) to enhance fetal lung maturity and reduce the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome. The correct dosing regimen for corticosteroids is crucial for their effectiveness.

 

Dexamethasone and Betamethasone are the two corticosteroids commonly used for this purpose:

 

  • Dexamethasone is given as 6 mg intramuscularly every 12 hours, totaling four doses. This regimen ensures adequate fetal lung maturation by delivering consistent steroid levels over 48 hours.
  • Betamethasone is typically administered as 12 mg intramuscularly, given in two doses 24 hours apart. This regimen also effectively promotes fetal lung maturity but involves fewer doses compared to Dexamethasone.

 

In this specific case, the correct answer is Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses because it follows the standard protocol for promoting lung maturity in fetuses at risk of preterm birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For fetal lung maturity, the standard dosing regimen of Dexamethasone is 6 mg intramuscularly every 12 hours for a total of 4 doses. This regimen is effective in reducing the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome in preterm infants.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for a benign tumor of the superficial parotid gland on FNAC? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superficial parotidectomy

 

The preferred treatment for a benign tumor of the parotid gland, as confirmed by fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC), is:

 

This is the treatment of choice for a benign parotid tumors like pleomorphic adenoma. It involves the surgical removal of the entire superficial lobe. Enucleation or simple excision is avoided as the tumor has projections (pseudopodia) which may be left behind leading to recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wide local incision: This is not typically performed for benign parotid tumors. However, now a days it is becoming an alternate to superficial parotidectomy.

 

Option C. Chemotherapy: This is not a standard treatment for benign parotid tumors as they are typically not responsive to chemotherapy agents.

 

Option D. Radiation therapy: Radiation therapy is not a standard treatment for benign parotid tumors as it is generally reserved for cancer treatment and not indicated for benign conditions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Superficial parotidectomy is the preferred treatment for a benign tumors like pleomorphic adenoma, providing targeted removal of the entire superficial lobe.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with fever, loose stools, and blood in the stool. What is the enrichment medium used to isolate the organism from the stool sample? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Selenite F broth

 

The given clinical vignette of dysentery (bloody stools) and abdominal pain in a child is suggestive of bacillary dysentery most likely caused due to Shigella. Selenite F broth is used as an enrichment media for dysentery-causing bacteria like Shigella/ Salmonella.

 

Enrichment media:

 

It is used to suppress commensal bacteria while allowing the pathogen to remain viable and grow. Common examples include:

 

  • Tetrathionate broth - It inhibits coliforms and allows typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli to grow.
  • Selenite F broth - used for dysentery causing bacteria.
  • Alkaline peptone water (Option-B) - used for vibrio cholera causing watery diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Robertson cooked meat broth: This medium is primarily used for the cultivation of anaerobic bacteria, not typically involved in cases of dysentery.

 

Option B. Alkaline peptone water: This is used for the enrichment of Vibrio species, particularly in cases suspected of cholera, which typically presents with watery diarrhea rather than bloody stools.

 

Option D. Brain heart infusion broth: It is an enriched media. It is used for the cultivation of fastidious organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selenite F broth is specifically used as an enrichment medium for isolating Shigella from stool samples in cases presenting with symptoms of dysentery, characterized by blood in the stools. This selective medium helps in the effective recovery of pathogens responsible for dysentery, aiding in accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

 

Dysentery/Shigellosis is a type of food poisoning caused by infection with the Shigella species. It is spread through faeco-oral transmission. They are catalase-negative, non-lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rods, and are non-motile. It acts by inactivating the 60s ribosomal subunit thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. It causes acute onset of symptoms (fever, abdominal cramps) with dysentery and tenesmus. It also gives a positive Sereny test.

questions.text: Inhibitor A and B are: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Competitive and non-competitive

 

Inhibitor A is a competitive inhibitor, and Inhibitor B is a non-competitive inhibitor.

 

  • Competitive Inhibition (Inhibitor A): In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding to the active site of the enzyme. This means that increasing the concentration of the substrate can overcome the inhibition. In this scenario, the maximum velocity (Vmax) of the reaction remains unchanged because, at high substrate concentrations, the enzyme can still achieve its maximum rate. However, the apparent affinity of the enzyme for the substrate decreases, leading to an increase in the Michaelis constant (Km). On a Lineweaver-Burk plot, competitive inhibition is indicated by lines that intersect on the y-axis, which represents no change in Vmax but a change in Km.
  • Non-Competitive Inhibition (Inhibitor B): Non-competitive inhibitors bind to an allosteric site rather than the active site, and their binding is not affected by the substrate concentration. As a result, the inhibition cannot be overcome by adding more substrate. Non-competitive inhibition leads to a decrease in the Vmax because the inhibitor reduces the overall number of active enzymes. However, Km remains unchanged because the binding of the inhibitor does not affect the affinity of the enzyme for the substrate. On a Lineweaver-Burk plot, non-competitive inhibition is indicated by lines that intersect on the x-axis, reflecting no change in Km but a decrease in Vmax.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uncompetitive and non-competitive: Uncompetitive inhibitors bind only to the enzyme-substrate complex, not to the free enzyme. This binding decreases both Km and Vmax because the inhibitor effectively removes some enzyme-substrate complexes from the reaction. This option is incorrect because Inhibitor A shows characteristics of competitive inhibition, not uncompetitive inhibition.

 

Option C. Non-competitive and uncompetitive: This option is incorrect because Inhibitor A is competitive, not non-competitive, and Inhibitor B is non-competitive, not uncompetitive. Therefore, this combination does not accurately represent the inhibition types for Inhibitor A and B.

 

Option D. Non-competitive and competitive: This option is incorrect because it reverses the correct inhibition types for Inhibitor A and B. Inhibitor A is competitive, while Inhibitor B is non-competitive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Remember that competitive inhibitors increase Km but do not change Vmax, while non-competitive inhibitors decrease Vmax but do not change Km.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with weight gain and hyperpigmentation of palms and soles. He was subsequently diagnosed to have lung cancer. Which of the following is responsible for hyperpigmentation? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Melanocyte Stimulating Hormone (MSH)

 

Explanation:

 

The patient, a chronic smoker, presented with weight gain and hyperpigmentation of the palms and soles and was diagnosed with lung cancer. This clinical scenario suggests the presence of an ectopic ACTH-producing tumor, most commonly associated with small cell lung cancer.

 

In such cases, the excessive ACTH produced by the tumor can lead to Cushing's syndrome.

 

Additionally, ACTH has an intrinsic MSH (Melanocyte Stimulating Hormone) activity due to the shared precursor molecule, proopiomelanocortin (POMC). The MSH part within ACTH stimulates melanocytes, leading to increased melanin production and resulting in hyperpigmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemosiderin: Hemosiderin is an iron-storage complex. It does not play a role in causing hyperpigmentation in this context.

 

Option C. Neuropeptide Y: Neuropeptide Y is involved in various physiological processes, including regulation of appetite and stress responses, but not in causing hyperpigmentation.

 

Option D. Melanin: While melanin is the pigment responsible for skin color, its production is stimulated by MSH. Thus, MSH is the direct cause of increased melanin and subsequent hyperpigmentation in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of ectopic ACTH production, such as with small cell lung cancer, hyperpigmentation occurs due to the MSH activity of ACTH, which stimulates melanocytes to produce melanin.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered ineffective in the prevention of COVID-19? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ivermectin

 

Ivermectin has been extensively studied during the COVID-19 pandemic but has not demonstrated any proven efficacy in preventing COVID-19 infection. Despite creating headlines during the pandemic period, clinical studies have not provided strong evidence that ivermectin reduces the risk of transmission or acquisition of COVID-19.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mask: Wearing masks has been proven to be an effective preventive measure in reducing the transmission of COVID-19 by providing a physical barrier against respiratory droplets.

 

Option B. Vaccine: Vaccines serve as pre-exposure prophylaxis and have been demonstrated to be effective in preventing severe COVID-19 infection and reducing transmission.

 

Option D. Cough etiquette: Proper cough etiquette is an important preventive measure that helps reduce the spread of respiratory droplets containing the virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ivermectin, despite being widely discussed during the pandemic, has not been proven effective in preventing COVID-19 infection, unlike established preventive measures such as masks, vaccines, and proper cough etiquette.

questions.text: Tom-Smith arthritis destroys: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Femoral capital epiphysis

 

TOM SMITH ARTHRITIS

 

  • It is septic arthritis of hip in infants which destroy the cartilaginous femoral head rapidly and completely (chondrolysis).
  • It is caused by non-tuberculous bacteria.
  • This intra-articular infection in children peaks in first few years of life with 50% patients younger than 2 years of age.
  • Males affected more than females – 2:1 ratio
  • Hip joint is more commonly involved, followed by knee joint.
  • Risk factors:
    • Prematurity
    • Caesarean section
    • Treatment in NICU
    • Invasive procedures like umbilical/venous catheterization, heel puncture
       
  • Clinical features: 
    • Child presents with limp, unstable gait
    • Shortening of limb
    • Positive telescopy
    • Increased hip movements in all direction
    • Limb position – flexion, abduction, external rotation (FABER)
    • Fever
    • Unable to bear weight
       
  • In 55% cases, no organism is identified.
    • Streptococcus is most commonly seen in neonates
    • Staphylococcus aureus is commonly seen in children over 2 years of age
    • Neisseria gonorrhoeae is commonly seen in adolescents
       
  • Kocher criteria is used for diagnosis:
    • WBC > 12,000 cells/ml of serum
    • Inability to bear weight
    • Fever > 101.3°F
    • ESR > 40 mm/h
    • Additional criteria – CRP (Modified Kocher criteria)
       
  • Investigations:
    • Elevated WBC – leukopenia
    • Elevated ESR – may be normal in early course of infection
    • CRP may increase in first 6-8 hours of infection
    • Hip aspirate will show high WBC, low glucose levels, high lactic acid levels
       
  • Radiographic findings:
    • X-ray may be normal in early stages
    • Shows widening of joint space, subluxation/dislocation

 

 

  • Treatment: 
    • Non-operative: antibiotics
    • Operative: surgical irrigation and debridement followed by IV antibiotics
       
  • Prognosis:
    • Good prognosis
    • Delayed diagnosis may result in permanent joint damage and long-term disability. 
    • Long-term morbidity includes acetabular dysplasia, subluxation and dislocation, cartilage necrosis, limb length discrepancy, abnormal/premature closure of proximal femoral physis, ischemic necrosis, and complete destruction of femoral head
    • Poor prognostic factors:
      • Age < 6 months
      • Associated osteomyelitis
      • Delay of > 4 days until presentation
      • Hip joint involvement

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetabular roof. Acetabular roof lesions are uncommon in children. If they occur, their cause can be eosinophilic granuloma, ewing’s sarcoma, non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, metastases, and neuroblastoma.

 

 

Option C. Femoral neck. Femoral neck is affected in children in femoral neck fractures due to high-impact injuries, but this is uncommon. Benign bone tumors or tumor-like bone lesions in the femoral neck can also be the cause.

 

Option D. Greater trochanter. Avulsion fractures of greater trochanter are very rare in children. They can be secondary to gluteal muscle contraction, femoral neck fracture, hip dislocation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tom smith arthritis or the septic arthritis in children, most commonly affects the femoral capital epiphysis.

questions.text: The defined population norm for Urban-Primary health centre in our country is one such centre per: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 per 50,000

 

In India, the population norm for establishing a UPHC is one center per 50,000 population. These centers are intended to provide primary healthcare services in urban areas, addressing the healthcare needs of urban populations efficiently.

 

The UPHCs are equipped to deliver a range of health services, including preventive, promotive, curative, and rehabilitative care.

 

In UPHC, one Urban Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM) per 10,000 population, and one Urban Social Health Activist (USHA) per 1,000 to 2,500 population.

 

Remember –

 

Population norm for rural PHC

 

  • 1 per 30,000 populations in plain area
  • 1 per 20,000 populations in tribal and hilly areas

 

Educational Objective:

 

The population norm for establishing an Urban Primary Health Centre (UPHC) in India is one center per 50,000 populations.

questions.text: A patient feels that someone is inserting some thoughts in his mind. What is the diagnosis?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Delusion of influence

 

The patient's experience of someone inserting thoughts into their mind is best described as thought insertion, a type of delusion where an individual believes that external forces are controlling their thoughts. This phenomenon falls under the category of delusion of influence, where a person feels that their thoughts, feelings, or actions are being controlled or influenced by an external source. This is also known as a passivity phenomenon, where the individual feels passive and controlled by others.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nihilistic delusion: This involves a belief that oneself, others, or the world does not exist or is coming to an end. For example, a patient might believe their internal organs are rotten or that the world has stopped.

 

Option C. Othello syndrome: This is a delusional belief of infidelity, where the patient is convinced that their partner is unfaithful.

 

Option D. Delusion of reference: This involves the belief that common elements of the environment are directly related to the individual, such as thinking people are talking about them or that events are directed at them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A delusion of influence involves the belief that an external force is controlling one's thoughts, feelings, or actions. This phenomenon is also known as thought insertion or passivity phenomenon.

choices.text: All boys and girl children equally affected
50% boys affected and no girl children unaffected
No boy affected and 50% children are carriers
25% boy affected and 25% girl children are carrier

questions.text: A boy born to a normal father and mother had Hemophilia. Detailed history taking revealed that the mother's side had a family history of similar affected individuals. The children born to this boy are likely to have which of the following? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) No boy affected and 50% children are carriers

 

Hemophilia is an X-linked recessive disorder, where affected males inherit the defective gene from their carrier mothers. In this scenario, the boy with hemophilia cannot pass the X-linked defective gene to his sons (as they inherit his Y chromosome). Therefore, no male children will be affected.

 

However, all daughters will inherit his X chromosome, meaning that 50% of his children (only daughters and not boys) shall be carriers of the hemophilia gene but will not exhibit the disease because they inherit a normal X chromosome from their mother.

 

Outcome:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All boys and girl children equally affected: This is incorrect because, due to the X-linked recessive nature of hemophilia, the affected father does not pass the defective X chromosome to his sons.

 

Option B. 50% boys affected and no girl children unaffected: This statement is incorrect as affected fathers cannot transmit the X-linked gene to their sons; only daughters can inherit the X chromosome.

 

Option D. 25% boy affected and 25% girl children are carrier: This does not match the inheritance pattern of X-linked recessive disorders, as male offspring will never inherit the disease from their father, and all daughters will have a 50% chance of being carriers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In X-linked recessive disorders like hemophilia, affected males do not transmit the condition to their sons, but their daughters have a 50% chance of being carriers.

 

Major X-linked Recessive Disorders (Mnemonic: "OBLIGATE"):

 

 

Other X-linked Recessive Diseases:

questions.text: Pipkin’s Fracture refers to a fracture of the (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Femoral Head

 

Pipkin's fracture refers to a fracture of the femoral head, which typically occurs in association with posterior hip dislocation. This injury results from a high-energy trauma like dashboard injuries in motor vehicle accidents. The Pipkin classification divides these fractures into four types based on the location of the fracture relative to the fovea centralis and associated injuries. These fractures are serious injuries that often require surgical intervention to restore joint congruity and prevent complications like avascular necrosis and post-traumatic arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Distal Tibia - Fractures of the distal tibia involving the articular surface are classified as pilon fractures or Ruedi-Allgower fractures, not Pipkin fractures.

 

Option C. Humeral Head - Fractures of the humeral head are part of proximal humerus fractures, which are classified by Neer's classification, not Pipkin's.

 

Option D. Distal Radius - Fractures of the distal radius are commonly classified as Colles' fractures, Smith's fractures, or Barton's fractures depending on the pattern. They are not related to Pipkin's classification.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pipkin's fracture is a specific type of femoral head fracture associated with posterior hip dislocation, representing a serious injury that often requires surgical management and carries risk of significant complications.

questions.text: Identify the condition represented in the image below: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Miliary tuberculosis

 

The above image represents “miliary tuberculosis”. Individual lesions are small (2-mm) foci of yellow-white consolidation scattered through the lung parenchyma.

 

Miliary tuberculosis is lymphohematogenous spread of tuberculous infection from primary focus or later stages of tuberculosis. The spread may occur to systemic organs or isolated organ. The spread is either by entry of infection into pulmonary vein producing disseminated or isolated organ lesion in different extra-pulmonary sites (e.g. liver, spleen, kidney, brain and bone marrow) or into pulmonary artery restricting the development of miliary lesions within the lung. The miliary lesions are millet seed-sized (1 mm diameter), yellowish, firm areas without grossly visible caseation necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emphysema: This condition is characterized by the abnormal, permanent enlargement of airspaces distal to the terminal bronchioles and the destruction of the alveolar walls. Large subpleural bullae (air-filled spaces >1 cm) may be present, especially in paraseptal emphysema.

 

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis: Typically presents with non-caseating granulomas.

 

 

Option D. Asbestosis: Associated with fibrous thickening and plaque formation primarily in the lung bases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Miliary tuberculosis appears as small, millet seed-sized yellowish foci scattered throughout the lung parenchyma, indicative of widespread hematogenous dissemination of tuberculosis.

choices.text: Spiral artery by villous trophoblasts
Radial artery by cytotrophoblasts
Spiral artery by extravillous trophoblasts
Arcuate artery by extravillous trophoblasts

questions.text: A pregnant woman with no other comorbid conditions develops preeclampsia. She enquires about the cause of her condition. The doctor explains that it is due to the failure of the invasion of? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spiral artery by extravillous trophoblasts

 

Explanation:

 

  • Preeclampsia occurs due to the failure of the invasion of extravillous trophoblasts into the spiral artery.
  • The spiral artery supplies blood to the endometrium. In normal pregnancy, there is an invasion of the extravillous trophoblasts (specifically, endovascular trophoblasts) into the walls of the spiral arteries.
  • This process takes place in two waves:
    • First wave (10-12 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the decidual segments.
    • Second wave (16-18 weeks): Endovascular trophoblasts invade up to the myometrial segments.
  • This invasion results in the distension of the spiral arterioles, transforming them into a low-resistance, low-pressure, and high-flow system.
  • In preeclampsia, the failure of the second wave of endovascular trophoblastic invasion into uterine vessels leads to decreased placental perfusion.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Spiral artery by villous trophoblasts: Villous trophoblasts are involved in the formation of the placental villi, but they do not invade the spiral arteries.

 

Option B. Radial artery by cytotrophoblasts: The radial arteries supply the deeper layers of the myometrium and are not primarily involved in the pathogenesis of preeclampsia.

 

Option D. Arcuate artery by extravillous trophoblasts: The arcuate arteries are part of the uterine arterial system, but their invasion by trophoblasts is not relevant to the development of preeclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preeclampsia is caused by the failure of extravillous trophoblasts to invade the spiral arteries, leading to decreased placental perfusion.

 

Ref: Page no 1818, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 45-year-old male came with a history of progressive dysphagia, initially to solid foods and now to liquids too. He has also experienced significant weight loss over the past few months. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for diagnosing the underlying cause of his symptoms? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper GI Endoscopy 

 

The patient's symptoms of progressive dysphagia first to solids and then to liquids, along with significant weight loss, are concerning for an esophageal pathology, possibly a malignancy. 

 

This is the investigation of choice for evaluating dysphagia. It allows direct visualization of the esophageal lumen, can detect strictures, masses, or other abnormalities, and offers the possibility of biopsy, which is essential for diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endoscopic ultrasound: This can provide detailed images of the esophageal wall and adjacent structures and is useful for staging esophageal cancer. It is generally not the first test ordered when investigating dysphagia.

 

Option C. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT): While CECT can provide information about the extent of a disease and help in staging cancer, it is not the first-line investigation for dysphagia and cannot provide a definitive diagnosis without endoscopic visualization and biopsy.

 

Option D. Barium swallow: A barium swallow X-ray study can show structural changes in the esophagus, such as narrowing or obstruction, and is useful in diagnosing conditions like achalasia or strictures. However, it is less definitive than endoscopy for tissue diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Upper GI endoscopy is the first-line diagnostic tool for evaluating a patient with progressive dysphagia and significant weight loss, as it allows for direct visualization and biopsy to establish a definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the Miami criteria for intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) measurement? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Half fall in 10 min

 

Half fall in 10 min: This is correct. The Miami Criteria for successful parathyroidectomy require a drop in PTH level of more than 50% from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the removal of the hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue.

 

The Miami Criteria, also known as the Miami Intraoperative Criteria, refers to a set of guidelines used to confirm successful removal of hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue during parathyroidectomy. The criteria are based on intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels.

 

According to the Miami Criteria, a successful parathyroidectomy is indicated if there is a drop in PTH level of more than 50% (half) from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the excision of the adenoma. This significant decrease indicates that the source of excess PTH production has been successfully removed.

 

The utility of this approach is that it allows for immediate feedback during surgery about whether all hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue has been removed, reducing the chances of persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism post-operatively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quarter fall in 5 min: This is incorrect. The Miami Criteria specify a 50% (half) fall, not a 25% (quarter) fall, and the timeframe is 10 minutes, not 5 minutes.

 

Option B. Quarter fall in 10 min: This is incorrect. While the 10-minute timeframe is correct, the required decrease is 50% (half), not 25% (quarter).

 

Option C. Half fall in 5 min: This is incorrect. Although the 50% (half) fall is correct, the timeframe specified by the Miami Criteria is 10 minutes, not 5 minutes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Miami Criteria for intraoperative PTH measurement indicate a successful parathyroidectomy if there is a 50% or greater drop in PTH level from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the excision of the hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland.

choices.text: Sertoli cell only syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Benign testicular neoplasm

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is evaluated for primary infertility. Semen analysis shows azoospermia. A testicular biopsy is done and the image is shown below. The shown finding is consistent with? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sertoli cell only syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

  • Sertoli cell only syndrome:
    • The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
    • Patients with Sertoli cell-only syndrome typically present between the ages of 20 and 40 years with primary infertility.
    • Diagnosis is confirmed through testicular biopsy.
    • The histopathology of the biopsy specimen typically shows seminiferous tubules populated by only Sertoli cells, with thickening of the tubular basement membrane and absence of germ cells, which is characteristic of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Testicular atrophy: Testicular atrophy may present with decreased testicular volume and could be due to various causes like mumps orchitis, trauma, or varicocele. The histopathological findings would not specifically show the absence of germ cells with the presence of only Sertoli cells.

 

Option C. Benign testicular neoplasm: Benign testicular neoplasms would present with a mass in the testis and would show specific neoplastic cells on histopathology rather than the absence of germ cells.

 

Option D. Orchitis: Orchitis typically presents with inflammation, pain, and swelling of the testes, and the biopsy would show inflammatory infiltrates rather than the absence of germ cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sertoli cell-only syndrome is characterized by primary infertility and azoospermia, with testicular biopsy showing seminiferous tubules populated only by Sertoli cells and absence of germ cells.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7910341/

questions.text: Identify the organism and the staining method used in the provided image. (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia acid fast stain

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows filamentous bacteria with partial acid-fastness, characteristic of Nocardia species stained using an acid-fast technique.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Streptococcus gram stain: Shows gram-positive cocci, not filamentous bacteria.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus india ink: Would reveal spherical yeast forms with a clear halo.

 

Option D. Coccidioidomycosis PAS stain: Typically shows spherules rather than filamentous structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia species are identified using an acid-fast stain, which highlights their filamentous and partially acid-fast nature.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman with a history of chronic sun exposure presented with bilateral brownish pigmentation over the face as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Melasma

 

Melasma is characterized by bilateral, symmetrical brownish pigmentation, primarily on the face, commonly seen in pregnant women or individuals with chronic sun exposure. In this case, the patient's history of pregnancy and chronic sun exposure, along with the image showing patchy pigmentation, strongly suggests melasma. Melasma in pregnant women is often referred to as chloasma or the "mask of pregnancy." It is associated with hormonal changes and UV exposure. Additionally, melasma is often linked to thyroid disorders.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanoma: Melanoma is typically characterized by the ABCDE features: Asymmetry, Border irregularity, Color variation, Diameter greater than 6mm, and Evolution of the lesion.

 

 

Option C. Suntan: A suntan results in diffuse pigmentation over sun-exposed areas, usually with an initial red phase. The pigmentation in a suntan is not patchy as seen in the image provided but rather more uniform. Therefore, suntan is not the correct diagnosis.

 

 

Option D. Nevus of OTA: This condition presents with unilateral blue or grey pigmentation, often involving the sclera and skin on the face. The absence of these characteristic features and the presence of bilateral brown pigmentation make Nevus of OTA an incorrect choice.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melasma, especially in pregnant women, presents as bilateral, symmetrical brownish patches on the face, often linked to sun exposure and hormonal changes.

choices.text: Basal stent placement

questions.text: Interventional technique used for the management of cerebral aneurysm: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coiling

 

The management of cerebral aneurysms, particularly berry aneurysms, involves two primary interventional techniques: clipping and coiling.

 

  • Coiling: This is an endovascular procedure where a catheter is inserted through the femoral artery and navigated to the aneurysm. Coils are then deployed into the aneurysm to induce thrombosis and prevent rupture. Coiling has lower morbidity and mortality rates compared to surgical clipping and is preferred if the aneurysm is accessible for endovascular treatment.
  • Clipping: This involves a craniotomy where the skull is opened, and a clip is placed at the neck of the aneurysm to isolate it from the circulation. While effective, it is more invasive compared to coiling.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Embolization: While embolization is used in various vascular interventions, it is not the preferred technique for managing cerebral aneurysms.

 

Option C. Basal stent placement: Stents may be used as an adjunct to coiling to support the coil mass and ensure complete occlusion of the aneurysm, but stent placement alone is not effective for managing aneurysms.

 

Option D. Balloon Angioplasty: This technique is used to dilate narrowed blood vessels but is not suitable for treating aneurysms as it can worsen the aneurysm by increasing the risk of rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred interventional technique for the management of cerebral aneurysms is endovascular coiling due to its lower morbidity and mortality compared to surgical clipping.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old child presents with altered sensorium, persistent headache, and photophobia for the past 5 days. On examination, he has signs of meningeal irritation. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals:what is your diagnosis?
Protein: 93 mg/dL


Glucose: 20 mg/dL (serum glucose = 90 mg/dL)


Cell count: Predominantly lymphocytic pleocytosis (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tubercular meningitis

 

  • Tubercular meningitis is often associated with CSF findings of elevated protein, decreased glucose, and lymphocytic pleocytosis. These findings are consistent with the given CSF results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis: The CSF findings of elevated protein, decreased glucose, and an increased number of neutrophil predominance (not lymphocytes) are suggestive of meningitis. However, bacterial meningitis is more commonly associated with a significantly higher white blood cell count (pleocytosis) in the CSF. The given CSF results are not typical for bacterial meningitis.

 

Option B. Viral meningitis: This is a potential consideration. Viral meningitis can present with elevated protein, normal or mildly reduced glucose, and an increased number of lymphocytes in the CSF. It is a common cause of aseptic (non-bacterial) meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: During periods of starvation, which of the following tissues primarily utilizes ketone bodies as an energy source? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brain

 

Explanation:

 

The brain is the primary tissue that utilizes ketone bodies as an energy source during starvation. When glucose levels are low during prolonged fasting or starvation, the brain shifts from relying on glucose to using ketone bodies (acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate) as its main fuel source. The brain can derive up to 75% of its energy requirements from ketone bodies during prolonged starvation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Erythrocytes: Erythrocytes (red blood cells) lack mitochondria and therefore cannot utilize ketone bodies, which require mitochondrial metabolism. They rely exclusively on glucose via glycolysis for their energy needs.

 

Option C. Liver: The liver is the main site of ketone body production but cannot utilize ketone bodies itself because it lacks the enzyme thiophorase, which is necessary for ketone body utilization.

 

Option D. All of the above: This is incorrect because both erythrocytes and liver cannot utilize ketone bodies as explained above.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

During starvation, the brain adapts to use ketone bodies as an alternative fuel source when glucose is limited, while the liver produces but cannot use ketone bodies, and erythrocytes remain dependent on glucose metabolism.

questions.text: During delivery of a 30y G2P1L1 with previous LSCS, the head was delivered but the shoulders got stuck. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shoulder dystocia

 

Shoulder dystocia is an obstetric emergency where, after the delivery of the fetal head, the shoulders fail to deliver within a typical interval. The definition of shoulder dystocia includes a delivery interval between the head and the shoulders exceeding one minute or requiring specific maneuvers to release the shoulders. This condition occurs when the fetal anterior shoulder impacts behind the maternal pubic symphysis or, less commonly, the posterior shoulder impacts the sacral promontory.

 

In this scenario, the head was delivered, but the shoulders got stuck, fitting the clinical definition of shoulder dystocia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CPD (Cephalopelvic Disproportion): This is incorrect as CPD refers to a mismatch between the size of the fetal head and the maternal pelvis, preventing the fetal head from entering or passing through the birth canal. It does not specifically describe the situation where the shoulders get stuck after the head is delivered.

 

Option C. Occipito posterior: This option is incorrect because it refers to the fetal head being positioned posteriorly in the pelvis, which can cause prolonged labor but does not directly result in shoulder dystocia. In occipito posterior positions, the delivery complication is typically a "face to pubis" delivery, not shoulder entrapment.

 

Option D. Transverse lie: This is incorrect as it describes a fetal position where the fetus lies horizontally in the uterus, which leads to complications like neglected shoulder with hand prolapse if the membranes rupture. The presentation is the shoulder, not the head, which means it does not fit the scenario where the head is delivered but the shoulders are stuck.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shoulder dystocia is diagnosed when the shoulders fail to deliver within a minute after the head or require specific maneuvers for delivery.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Bladder exstrophy

 

Bladder exstrophy is a congenital condition characterized by the abnormal development of the bladder and lower abdominal wall, resulting in the bladder being exposed outside the body. The image shows a typical presentation of bladder exstrophy, with the bladder visible as a red mass on the lower abdomen of the newborn. This condition requires surgical correction to reconstruct the bladder and close the abdominal wall defect.

 

Other Options:

 

Open A. Umbilical hernia: An umbilical hernia is characterized by the protrusion of abdominal contents through an opening in the abdominal muscles near the umbilicus. It typically presents as a soft bulge near the belly button, which is reducible and covered by skin, differing from the exposed bladder seen in bladder exstrophy.

 

Open B. Omphalocele: Omphalocele is a congenital defect where the abdominal contents, such as intestines, liver, and other organs, herniate through the base of the umbilical cord and are covered by a protective membrane. It does not involve exposure of the bladder and is distinct from bladder exstrophy.

 

Option D. Gastroschisis: It is an abdominal wall defect where intestines are protruding, but lack a peritoneal covering. The defect is usually to the right side of umbilicus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bladder exstrophy presents with the bladder exposed outside the abdominal wall, requiring prompt surgical intervention to correct the defect and reconstruct the urinary tract.

choices.text: Excellent prognosis is associated with this condition.
Nuclear characteristics are used for identification.
Fine needle aspiration cytology (FAC) is not diagnostic.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with a midline swelling in the neck. Upon examination, cervical node enlargement is also observed. Histopathological analysis of the lesion reveals the following findings Identify the false statement of the following?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fine needle aspiration cytology (FAC) is not diagnostic.

 

  • The histopathological findings provided are indicative of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, which includes features such as papillary formation with a fibrovascular stalk, distinct orphan Annie nuclei, and psammoma bodies.
  • Fine needle aspiration cytology is actually a common and reliable diagnostic method for thyroid nodules, including papillary carcinoma.
  • By extracting cells from the thyroid nodule using a fine needle and examining them under a microscope, the presence of characteristic features of papillary carcinoma can be identified.
  •  Thus, the statement suggesting that FNAC is not diagnostic is false

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excellent prognosis is associated with this condition: This statement refers to the typical prognosis of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Papillary carcinoma, although malignant, is often slow-growing. When detected early and treated appropriately, patients generally have an excellent prognosis with a high survival rate.

 

Option B. It spreads via lymphatics: While papillary carcinoma often spreads via the lymphatics to regional lymph nodes (leading to cervical node enlargement, as seen in the patient), it typically does so at a slow rate. It's important to note that even when there is lymph node involvement, the prognosis still remains relatively favorable compared to other types of thyroid cancers.

 

Option C. Nuclear characteristics are used for identification: The nuclear features of papillary thyroid carcinoma are characteristic and aid in its identification. One such feature is the "orphan Annie eye" nuclei, which are large, empty-appearing nuclei. Other characteristics, like psammoma bodies, can also be present.

 

  • Given the context and the provided image findings indicative of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, FNAC is indeed diagnostic for this condition. Hence, option D is the false statement among the ones provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is a reliable and commonly used diagnostic method for thyroid nodules, including papillary carcinoma, as it can identify characteristic histopathological features.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe a study that is longitudinal, observational, and includes the analysis of variables to determine associations? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cohort study

 

Explanation:

 

  • The correct term for a longitudinal, observational study that involves the analysis of variables to determine associations among a group of people is a "cohort study”.
  • In a cohort study, participants are followed over time to see how different exposures affect their chances of developing an outcome. 
  • It's useful for studying the effects of suspected risk factors that cannot be controlled experimentally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Case-Control Study: This type of study involves identifying participants based on the presence (case) or absence (control) of a particular outcome or disease and then looking back retrospectively to compare exposure to a risk factor or intervention between the groups.

 

Option C. Ecological Study: These studies assess risk factors or outcomes in a population based on data at the group level, rather than individual data. It's useful for initial, broad correlations between environmental or contextual factors and health outcomes.

 

Option D. Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT): This is an experimental study where participants are randomly assigned to either the group receiving the intervention or to a control group that does not, to compare outcomes in a controlled way.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For analyzing how various factors might affect health outcomes over time within a specified group, a cohort study is typically the most appropriate method due to its ability to follow participants through time and observe changes and outcomes as they occur naturally.

questions.text: Amsel criteria is used for? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bacterial vaginosis

 

Explanation:

 

Amsel's criteria are used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis (BV). The diagnosis requires at least three out of the following four criteria to be present:

 

  1. Homogeneous, thin, white discharge that smoothly coats the vaginal walls.
  2. Clue cells on microscopy: Vaginal epithelial cells that appear stippled with bacteria.
  3. Positive whiff test: A fishy odor is released when a solution of 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) is added to a sample of the vaginal discharge.
  4. Vaginal pH > 4.5: An elevated pH is indicative of BV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Candidiasis: Diagnosed primarily by clinical presentation and microscopic identification of yeast cells or pseudo hyphae.

 

Option C. Cervicitis: Diagnosed based on clinical findings and specific laboratory tests for pathogens like Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

Option D. Trichomoniasis: Diagnosed by identifying the flagellated protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis on a wet mount microscopy or by specific antigen tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amsel criteria are specifically used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis, requiring the presence of at least three out of four specific clinical and laboratory findings.

choices.text: Esophageal veins and left gastric veins
Left colic vein and middle colic veins

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with chronic liver disease presents with abdominal pain, jaundice, and signs of portal hypertension. Which of the following venous anastomoses is most likely responsible for this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Esophageal veins and left gastric veins

 

In the given scenario of a patient with portal hypertension, anastomosis between esophageal veins and left gastric veins can be seen.

 

In portal hypertension, increased pressure within the portal venous system may result in the dilation of portal venous tributaries and reversed flow at sites of portosystemic anastomoses.

 

The patient's presentation of abdominal pain, jaundice, and portal hypertension suggests an obstruction of the portal venous system, leading to the formation of portosystemic anastomoses. These are communications between the portal venous system and systemic venous system, which allow blood from the abdominal organs to bypass the liver and flow directly into the systemic circulation.

 

The lower esophageal veins, which drain into the systemic circulation via the azygos system, can anastomose with the left gastric veins (which are part of the portal system). In the context of portal hypertension, such as from cirrhosis, the blood flow through this anastomosis increases, leading to the formation of esophageal varices. These are dilated veins in the esophagus and are at risk of rupture, which can result in significant and potentially fatal bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left colic vein and middle colic veins:  Both these veins are tributaries of the inferior mesenteric vein and subsequently drain into the portal system. They do not form a portosystemic anastomosis.

 

  • Clinical Importance: These veins aren't directly associated with the complications of portal hypertension.

 

Option C. Superior rectal and phrenic veins:  The superior rectal veins are branches of the inferior mesenteric vein and drain into the portal system, while the phrenic veins are systemic veins. However, these two veins do not directly anastomose.

 

  • Clinical Importance: They do not play a significant role in the portosystemic shunting seen in portal hypertension.

 

Option D. Sigmoid and superior rectal veins: The sigmoid veins and superior rectal veins both drain into the inferior mesenteric vein, which is a part of the portal system. They do not form a portosystemic anastomosis.

 

  • Clinical Importance: They do not contribute significantly to the clinical features of portal hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common sites of Porto-systemic anastomoses and their clinical presentations are as follows:

choices.text: ADP ribosylation of EF2 Inhibiting protein synthesis

questions.text: Diphtheria toxin MOA is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ADP ribosylation of EF2 Inhibiting protein synthesis

 

Diphtheria toxin exerts its toxic effects by inhibiting protein synthesis in the host cell. The mechanism involves the ADP ribosylation of elongation factor 2 (EF-2), which is a critical component in the protein synthesis machinery of the cell. By modifying EF-2, diphtheria toxin prevents the translocation step in protein elongation, effectively halting protein production. This leads to cell death and contributes to the pathogenic effects of the infection.

 

Mnemonic "Delhi Public Secondary School" (DPSS): The four toxins that inhibit protein synthesis: Diphtheria toxin, Pseudomonas toxin, Shiga toxin, and Shiga-like toxin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acting on 60s Ribosome: This is incorrect because diphtheria toxin specifically targets elongation factor 2 (EF-2) rather than the ribosome directly. It interferes with protein synthesis by modifying EF-2, not by acting on the ribosome.

 

Option B. Increasing cAMP: This option is incorrect as it describes the mechanism of action of other bacterial toxins like those produced by Bacillus anthracis, Vibrio cholerae, Bordetella pertussis, and enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). These toxins increase the intracellular levels of cAMP by activating adenyl cyclase, which is not the mechanism for diphtheria toxin.

 

Option C. Decreasing cGMP: This is incorrect. The mechanism involving the decrease of cGMP is not relevant to diphtheria toxin. Diphtheria toxin's action is specific to inhibiting protein synthesis through the ADP ribosylation of EF-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MOA

 

The four toxins that inhibit protein synthesis by modifying EF-2: Diphtheria toxin, Pseudomonas toxin, Shiga toxin, and Shiga-like toxin. (Mnemonic: Delhi Public Secondary School /DPSS)

 

The four toxin act by increasing cAMP: Bacillus anthracis, Vibrio cholerae, Bordetella pertussis, and enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). (Mnemonic: Be Very Efficient Boy/BVEB)

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance
Small blood vessels are most radioresistant
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant

questions.text: A woman with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Which of the following is true? (NEET PF 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance

 

Explanation

 

This statement refers to the Inverse Square Law, which states that the intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source. This means that as the distance from the radiation source increases, the intensity of the radiation decreases exponentially. This law is fundamental in radiation physics and is crucial for understanding radiation exposure and protection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Small blood vessels are most radioresistant: This is incorrect. Larger vessels are more radioresistant compared to smaller ones. The endothelial cells lining small vessels are more susceptible to radiation damage due to their relatively higher rate of proliferation.

 

Option C. Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant: This is incorrect. Rapidly proliferating cells are the most radiosensitive. Cells that are dividing quickly, such as those in the gastrointestinal tract, bone marrow, and reproductive tissues, are more susceptible to radiation damage because radiation primarily affects DNA during cell division.

 

Option D. Small bowel is most radioresistant: This is incorrect. The gastrointestinal (GI) tract, including the small bowel, is among the most radiosensitive organ systems in the body. This high radiosensitivity is due to the rapid turnover of the epithelial cells lining the GI tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source, as described by the Inverse Square Law.

 

Ref: Page no 610, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a reddish, firm nodule on her chest that has not increased in size. The patient is concerned about the possibility of malignancy and undergoes a biopsy of the lesion. Histopathological examination of the biopsy specimen shows certain features that aid in the diagnosis. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hemangioma

 

A hemangioma is a benign tumor formed by a collection of excess blood vessels.

 

The histopathological features of hemangioma include:

 

  • A well-circumscribed lesion composed of dilated, thin-walled blood vessels.
  • The endothelial cells lining the vessels are flattened and uniform, with minimal mitotic activity.
  • The vessels are often arranged in lobules, with stromal cells separating the lobules.
  • The stromal cells are composed of fibroblasts, myofibroblasts, and/or pericytes.

 

In cases of cavernous hemangiomas, the vessels are larger and more dilated than those in capillary hemangiomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipoma: A lipoma is a benign tumor of adipose (fat) tissue and typically presents as a soft, rubbery lump that can be moved with slight finger pressure. On histopathology, a lipoma will show mature fat cells that are uniform in size. They don't exhibit much cellular variability, and there are no vascular proliferations like those seen in a hemangioma.

 

Option B. Fibroadenoma: Fibroadenoma is a benign breast tumor. It's composed of glandular and fibrous tissue. On physical examination, it often feels like a small, rubbery lump that moves around easily within the breast tissue. Histologically, fibroadenomas show a combination of glandular breast tissue and stromal tissue. They are not typically found on the chest but rather within the breast tissue itself, and their histological appearance would not match the vascular features of a hemangioma.

 

Option C. Nevus: A nevus, commonly referred to as a mole, is a benign skin lesion that contains nevomelanocytes. Nevus cells can be found in the epidermis, dermis, or both. Histologically, it would show nests of melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction, and/or in the dermis, depending on the type of nevus. It wouldn't have the vascular structures seen in a hemangioma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemangioma is a benign tumor formed by a collection of excess blood vessels, characterized histologically by well-circumscribed lesions composed of dilated, thin-walled blood vessels arranged in lobules.

questions.text: Night blindness history, corneal drying and patient has Bitot’s spots. Which of the following is found in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phrynoderma

 

The symptoms of patient clearly indicate vitamin A deficiency.
