One of the other clinical feature of vitamin A deficiency is follicular hyperkeratosis aka Phrynoderma which is characterized by excessive keratinization of certain area of body such as elbows and knees. Vitamin A prevents hyperkeratinization.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratosis pilaris rubra: Keratosis pilaris rubra is a skin condition characterized by the appearance of small, red bumps on the skin, often on the arms and thighs. It primarily affects the skin and does not directly relate to the symptoms described.

 

Option B. Eczema: Eczema is a chronic skin condition characterized by red, itchy, and inflamed skin patches. While eczema can affect the skin, it is not associated with night blindness, corneal drying, or Bitot's spots.

 

Option D. Ichthyosis: Ichthyosis is a group of genetic skin disorders that lead to dry, scaly, and thickened skin. It primarily affects the skin's texture and is not commonly associated with night blindness and corneal drying.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Symptoms of night blindness, corneal drying, and Bitot's spots, are indications of vitamin A deficiency. Phrynoderma, which is characterized by goosebump-like skin changes, is a manifestation of severe vitamin A deficiency and is the most relevant option in this context.

 

Ref-Dinesh Puri 3rd e/pg. 393,

questions.text: Maximum absorption of short-chain fatty acids produced by bacteria occurs in the: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Colon

 

Explanation:

 

Short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) are primarily produced in the colon and absorbed from it. These 2-5 carbon weak acids have an average concentration of about 80 mmol/L in the colonic lumen, with acetate (60%), propionate (25%), and butyrate (15%) being the predominant types. They form through bacterial fermentation of complex carbohydrates, resistant starches, and dietary fiber components that escape digestion in the upper gastrointestinal tract.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Stomach - The stomach primarily handles initial protein digestion and fat emulsification. The acidic environment is not conducive to the bacterial fermentation processes that generate SCFAs.
  • Option B. Duodenum - The duodenum is involved in the early stages of nutrient digestion with pancreatic enzymes and bile, but not in SCFA production or absorption. Bacterial populations needed for SCFA production are minimal here.
  • Option C. Jejunum - While the jejunum is a major site for nutrient absorption, it lacks the significant bacterial populations required for SCFA production. The relatively fast transit time also does not allow for substantial bacterial fermentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SCFAs are unique among fatty acids in that they're produced by bacterial fermentation in the colon and represent an important source of energy for colonic epithelial cells, helping maintain mucosal integrity and acid-base balance.

questions.text: A patient had a drop in Systolic Blood Pressure of 15 mm Hg during inspiration. Which of the following is NOT associated with it? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy

 

Explanation

 

A drop in systolic blood pressure of more than 10 mm Hg during inspiration is termed pulsus paradoxus. This phenomenon is seen in several conditions, including cardiac tamponade, status asthmaticus, and tension pneumothorax.

 

Cardiac tamponade is a classic cause of pulsus paradoxus due to the restriction of ventricular filling during inspiration. Status asthmaticus and tension pneumothorax also cause significant intrathoracic pressure changes, leading to a similar hemodynamic effect.

 

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, on the other hand, is not associated with pulsus paradoxus. Instead, HCM can be associated with pulsus bisferiens, a double-peaked pulse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardiac Tamponade: This is a well-known cause of pulsus paradoxus.

 

Option B. Status Asthmaticus: This can cause pulsus paradoxus due to severe obstruction and changes in intrathoracic pressure.

 

Option D. Tension Pneumothorax: This condition can also lead to pulsus paradoxus due to significant intrathoracic pressure changes.
 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulsus paradoxus, a significant drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration, is seen in conditions like cardiac tamponade, status asthmaticus, and tension pneumothorax. It is not associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which can present with pulsus bisferiens instead.

choices.text: Descending limb of the loop of Henle
Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle
Late distal tubule and collecting duct

questions.text: In a patient with severe central diabetes insipidus, which part of the tubule would have the lowest tubular fluid osmolality? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Late distal tubule and collecting duct

 

In central diabetes insipidus, there is a deficiency of ADH (vasopressin) secretion from the posterior pituitary. Without ADH, the collecting ducts become relatively impermeable to water. This causes the already dilute fluid entering from the distal tubule to remain hypotonic without the normal water reabsorption that would concentrate it. In diabetes insipidus, urine osmolality can be extremely low (50-100 mOsm/L) due to this lack of water reabsorption in the collecting ducts.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Proximal tubule - Incorrect because proximal tubular fluid remains essentially iso-osmotic with plasma (around 300 mOsm/kg) regardless of ADH status. About 60-70% of filtered water is reabsorbed here through aquaporin-1 channels that function independently of ADH.
  • Option B. Descending limb of the loop of Henle - Incorrect because tubular fluid becomes hypertonic in this segment as water moves out via aquaporin-1 channels into the hypertonic medullary interstitium. ADH status does not significantly affect this segment.
  • Option C. Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle - Incorrect because while this segment does create hypotonic fluid by actively transporting Na+, K+, and Cl- out of the tubule without water (it's water-impermeable), the tubular fluid becomes even more dilute as it continues through the distal tubule and collecting duct in the absence of ADH.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The late distal tubule and collecting duct display the lowest tubular fluid osmolality in central diabetes insipidus because these segments, which normally concentrate urine under ADH influence, remain impermeable to water without ADH, allowing maximally dilute fluid to be excreted.

choices.text: Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus association is high
Association with mucocutaneous candidiasis is high

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically associated with Autoimmune Polyendocrine Syndrome Type 1 (APS-1)? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus association is high

 

Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus does not have a high association with APS-1. The association is low and not a characteristic feature of APS-1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoparathyroidism is common: Hypoparathyroidism is common and is part of the classic triad of APS-1.

 

Option C. Association with mucocutaneous candidiasis is high: Mucocutaneous candidiasis is highly associated with APS-1. It is typically the first manifestation, appearing in infancy, and is also the most common manifestation due to underlying immunodeficiency.

 

Option D. Early onset in infancy: Early onset in infancy is characteristic of APS-1, with mucocutaneous candidiasis typically being the first manifestation to appear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classic triad of APS-1:

 

  1. Mucocutaneous candidiasis (most common and earliest manifestation)
  2. Hypoparathyroidism
  3. Addison's disease

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition from the given graph. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Competitive

 

The graph shown is a Lineweaver-Burk plot, which is a double reciprocal plot commonly used to illustrate enzyme kinetics. In this plot, the x-axis represents the reciprocal of the substrate concentration (1/[S]), and the y-axis represents the reciprocal of the reaction velocity (1/V). The graph is particularly useful in distinguishing different types of enzyme inhibition.

 

In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding to the active site of the enzyme. This type of inhibition is characterized by an increase in the apparent Km (Michaelis constant), which is reflected as a change in the slope of the Lineweaver-Burk plot. However, the Vmax (maximum velocity) remains unchanged because the effect of the inhibitor can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration.

 

In the Lineweaver-Burk plot, this is depicted as the two lines (with and without inhibitor) crossing at the y-axis. The y-intercept remains the same (indicating unchanged Vmax), but the slope changes due to the increase in apparent Km, which shifts the x-intercept closer to the origin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-competitive: In non-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds to a different site on the enzyme, not the active site. This binding reduces the overall number of active enzyme molecules, thereby decreasing Vmax without affecting Km. In a Lineweaver-Burk plot, this results in lines that intersect on the x-axis, not the y-axis.

 

 

Option C. Un-competitive: Un-competitive inhibition occurs when the inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, not to the free enzyme. This results in parallel lines in the Lineweaver-Burk plot, as both Km and Vmax decrease.

 

 

Option D. Allosteric: Allosteric inhibition involves the binding of an inhibitor to a site other than the active site, leading to changes in enzyme activity. This type of inhibition is more complex and isn't typically represented by a Lineweaver-Burk plot in the same way competitive, non-competitive, or un-competitive inhibitions are.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In competitive inhibition, the Lineweaver-Burk plot shows lines that cross at the y-axis, indicating that Vmax remains unchanged while Km increases due to the competition between the inhibitor and the substrate for the enzyme's active site.
